title: Westfield Corp in $US2.5 billion overseas expansion
text:
Westfield Corp runs the international business, which includes Westfield London.
Westfield Corp, the international retail business run by Steven and Peter Lowy, is embarking on $US2.5 billion ($3.5 billion) of projects in the coming year that will have it reopen the newly built World Trade Centre in New York by June.
The developments are happening against the backdrop of improving retail sales in its North American, British and Milan portfolios.
Having conquered the retail property sector, Westfield will look to expand into the residential market with plans for the construction of 2500 apartments adjoining the Westfield London and Stratford City shopping centres in the coming years.
Westfield reported a first-half profit of $US465.9 million ($652 million), which was in line with the forecasts made when the group restructured and created Scentre Group last year.
Advertisement Sales growth was broad based in all categories, with the international brands and luxury retailers showing solid gains. Net operating income growth was 4.2 per cent for the half-year. The higher-margin specialty sales increase was an average 10 per cent, with jewellery leading the charge, showing 15.6 per cent sales growth.
Since the restructure, Westfield has separated its malls into flagship and regional portfolios. The group will pump $US1.6 billion into the flagship portfolio, which includes Century City in Los Angeles, San Diego's UTC and Valley Fair in California's Silicon Valley.
It is also developing a mall in Milan in Italy that is to be anchored by upmarket French retailer Galeries Lafayette.
Funds From Operations (FFO) came in at $US380 million while the distribution for the six months to June 30 was 12.55¢ per security, also in line with forecast.
The UBS sales desk said the development business was on track and the stable portfolio was showing the benefit of focusing on high-quality centres.
Westfield's Peter Lowy and Steven Lowy said the benefits of the restructure could be seen in the progress made on the $US11.4 billion development program.
Steven Lowy said Westfield would also look to expand its digital offerings through Westfield Labs, with more ticketless parking in the US malls, to "connect the consumer both physically and digitally through our mall infrastructure".
"This year we expect to commence $US2.5 billion of projects, having already commenced $US1.6 billion of redevelopments to date in 2015 including Century City in Los Angeles and UTC in San Diego, with the expansion at Westfield London expected to commence later this year," he said.
"The $US1.4 billion Westfield World Trade Centre is now fully leased and committed. This will be a spectacular shopping, dining, event and entertainment destination integrated into the World Trade Centre Transportation Hub in Lower Manhattan."
The project will showcase a diverse mix of more than 100 domestic and international fashion, dining, beauty, entertainment and technology retailers as well as a "world-class" food offering, led by Eataly​, an Italian dining group. The project is now expected to open in the first half of 2016.
The distribution for the six months to June 30 was 12.55¢ per security.
The group reconfirmed its FFO forecast for the 2015 year of 37.7¢ per security, including the impact of the $US925 million O'Connor joint venture in the US that was completed in February.
The distribution forecast for the 2015 year was also reconfirmed at 25.1¢ per security.
